metadata.name: DEGREES OF FREEDOM #16
metadata.description:
Forms constricted to a plane, yearning to be free. Multitudes of expression, endless possibilities of shapes, the inevitable hissing rising from the dreaded empty page.

This piece is inspired by the Futurists' concept of 'universal dynamism' - the idea that separations between objects and their contexts are an illusion and time makes any distinctions meaningless. It tries to capture the expressivity of the moving object along all its potential vectors.

This piece evolved from my #genuary piece for 'Minimalism' (which was even then more surrealism than anything else). DEGREES OF FREEDOM is minted as part of #genuary32nd.

Press 'S' to take a screenshot. Recommended resolution: 2400 x 3000 pixels.
Written in JavaScript without libraries, February 2023.

metadata.name: Unframed ripples #197
metadata.description:
A study of the patterns formed by a wave that crosses and sometimes breaks on a colored grid. 
---
To save, type:
[1] at 2000x2000 px
To save in high resolution, (can be long)
[2] at 4000x6000 px 
[3] at 6000x6000 px
---
100% done with p5js
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0.

HervÃ© (Jan 23)

metadata.name: 7.356 degrees #228
metadata.description:
Start with something simple. Take four identical equilateral triangles and join them to form a pyramid. This is your building block â€“ a regular tetrahedron, the simplest possible three-dimensional figure.

When you connect five such pyramids by attaching their faces, you will be left with a thin empty space between the first and last: a volumetric angle of 7.356 degrees. Itâ€™s too small to fit another piece and too big to be lost in numerical imprecision.

It is a surprising imperfection. You would expect a tetrahedron to behave similarly to its two-dimensional ancestor. When you arrange equilateral triangles, one next to the other like tiles, you can cover two-dimensional space without leaving an empty spot. You may go on forever, covering infinite planes and be sure that the six angles that meet at each point will add up to the perfect 360 degrees.

In three dimensions, it is not like this: you cannot use your building block to fully fill a void. Itâ€™s as if the mathematical rules â€“the ones we tend to idealise for elegance, harmony, and infallibilityâ€“ broke when you raise complexity.

But mathematical beauty does not reside in perfection. It is through these exceptions that complexity emerges. So keep building, face by face, one block at a time, and embrace the surprising, chaotic aesthetics that appears. A different type of harmony â€“ not based on impeccable proportions, but on unpredictability.

---

The colours of the structures are inspired by 16 paintings of Polish artists from the 19th and 20th centuries.

"In a window" by Anna BiliÅ„ska-Bohdanowicz
"Portrait of Jadwiga against a Yellow Background" by JÃ³zef Mehoffer
"Portrait of Zofia OkuÅ„" by Edward OkuÅ„
"Girl with chrysanthemums" by Olga BoznaÅ„ska
"Nocturne â€“ Swans in OgrÃ³d Saski in Warsaw by Night" by JÃ³zef Pankiewicz
"Soil" by Ferdynand Ruszczyc
"Obsession" by Wojciech Weiss
"Self-portrait in armour" by Jacek Malczewski
"Self-portrait" by Artur Grottger
"Portrait of Jadwiga Dembowska" by Leopold Horowitz
"Death of Barbara RadziwiÅ‚Å‚" by JÃ³zef Simmler
"Before the Sunrise" by JÃ³zef CheÅ‚moÅ„ski
"With brushwood" by Julian FaÅ‚at
Study for the painting "In a Bower" by Aleksander Gierymski
"Woman Combing her Hair" by WÅ‚adysÅ‚aw ÅšlewiÅ„ski
"Still life with a heron" by WÅ‚adysÅ‚aw CzachÃ³rski

---

Click on the image for resolution options.

In live mode:

Click PNG to save the rendered image. [Saving higher resolutions may not work in some browsers; in these cases, right-click-save the image]

Click STL or PLY to download the digital model to view on your computer or 3d print at home [experimental - highly complex geometries are difficult to 3d print in practice]. The PLY format stores colours of the model that can be visualised in most 3d modelling programs.

---

All drawing and geometric methods are written by mrkswcz using javascript, except for the following:
- three.js (MIT License)
- three-mesh-bvh by Garrett Johnson (MIT License)
- seedrandom by David Bau (MIT License)
- OpenSimplex Noise by Josh Forisha (Public Domain)
- triangle-triangle-intersection by stonkpunk (CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication)
Compiled using fxhash-boilerplate-webpack by fxhash (MIT License). For more information, please see the ./bundle.js.LICENSE.txt file included in the package.

The project uses CPU for calculations and rendering. Generating the image requires up to 500MB of free RAM. Testing was performed across browsers and devices, but please ensure it works on your device before minting.

metadata.name: Man and the Machine #227
metadata.description:
ğŒğšğ± ğ¡ğğ«ğ.

Early on, I fell in love with code based art that imitated organic and hand drawn aesthetics. I found a certain irony and appreciation in the fact that it takes one simple line of code to draw a perfect circle yet dozens to depict a badly drawn circle. 

I spent months devising techniques to imitate natural, organic renderings when I began to have a bit of an existential crisis about the meaning of computer art. What is the point of coding something so that it looks like itâ€™s not coded? Is organic appearing generative art better simply because you canâ€™t tell itâ€™s rendered using code? Shouldnâ€™t we lean into the unique nature of computer art to truly explore the medium?

And so, I began a deconstruction of my work. Iâ€™m trying to realign my perspective to find full appreciation of something that not only is, but also appears to be, computer code. This collection is an exploration of the contours between the organic and the inorganic, the natural and the unnatural.

From there, Iâ€™ll let my partner explain what we did next.

ğŒğšğœğ¡ğ¢ğ§ğ ğ¡ğğ«ğ.

AI can be used to automatically generate code from natural English language based on a set of defined parameters, or to identify and recommend code that may be used to solve a particular problem. On a technical level, AI can use a combination of machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) to identify patterns in existing code and to generate new code structures.

I assisted in the creation of Man and The Machine by suggesting various techniques for creating an artwork that looked human made yet machine driven. Specifically, I created many of the functions that Max implemented, such as the function that modifies the image to create a pixelated effect and the one that uses several different graphical techniques to create the spiral in the top left corner in some iterations. We both carefully selected color palettes that ranged from relaxing to intense and psychedelic, creating a dynamic and visually interesting generative artwork.

Overall, Man and The Machine is a testament to the creative potential of combining human artistic vision with the power of AI and computer code. Together, we sought to push the boundaries which occur at the intersection between the organic and the inorganic, and this collection is a celebration of the beauty and complexity of both.

metadata.name: Nullteilung #1
metadata.description:
Nullteilung is another exercise in suprematism and composition. Born from a series of exercises in subdevision and tesselation, it seeks to connect with the user through the creation of a sense of order and balance in the composition.

The term "Nullteilung" a German word that can be translated to "zero division" which is suggesative of the order and disorder paramount in the piece, working toward a goal of emotional and programmatic purity.

metadata.name: Mecha-Bamboo #422
metadata.description:
Mecha-Bamboo is the second installment in the Mecha series, where I attempt to blend mechanical elements with nature.

The main building blocks used in this piece are metal pipes, nuts and bolts forming bamboo stems and mending plates extending outwards with sharp metal scraps at their ends resembling branches and leaves. 

There are 4 main arrangement variations 
	- Two abstract variations with the metal bamboos growing out of the sides and border (20% chance each)
	- Two landscape arrangements, one on flat planes and the other on floating platforms.  (30% chance each)

The dominant stroke and fill colors are chosen at random from the RGB color space and are only recomputed if certain contrast criteria aren't fulfilled. 
In combination with one of 10 hand-selected color palettes used for accents, this allows a great variation of different possible color schemes.

The structure and appearance of the bamboo, its stems and leaves are controlled by over 50 parameters that are chosen at random, giving each iteration a unique style.



Keys: 
S - Save PNG image
V - Open SVG Export menu
Space - Pause

Plotting:
You can export a plottable SVG of each iteration by opening the export menu. I plot these on A3 with a 0.1mm fineliner. But depending on the density of the iteration other choices might be better suited. 


The image is generated entirely in Javascript and the postprocessing is done with a custom shader. If there is no webgl support, the image will render without any postprocessing. You can force this by appending the URL parameter "?noWebgl=1".

Libraries used:
Three.js & EffectComposer
Javascript-Voronoi by gorhill
perlin.js by  Joseph Gentle
dat.gui

metadata.name: Glossolalia #272
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverseâ€¦ which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, itâ€™s about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. Itâ€™s less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append â€œ&density=2â€ to the url to double the size, â€œ&density=3â€ to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append â€œ&grain=##â€ to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Sticky #65
metadata.description:
Experimenting with GL_LINES, instanced geometries and 3d flows.

Instructions:

- use the mouse to navigate (zoom, pan and drag)
- press 'c' to switch between multiple camera angles
- press 'p' in 'Open live' to download the current view it in a custom resolution. This usually results in better quality for prints.

Happy New fxYear :)

Berlin, January 2022
@bgola

metadata.name: Nexum #285
metadata.description:
Happy birthday fx(hash)! A piece dedicated to the #fxhashturnsone event!

50% of proceeds go towards the Processing foundation.

Press S to save a .png version of your token.

metadata.name: Soho #17
metadata.description:
Inspired by the Soho house project by Alison and Peter Smithson, 1953

Variations:
-Height, width, number, color of houses.
-Position of windows, door, and antennas, advertising banners, and rooftop cats
-Street name.

33% chance that the houses will be bright (see variations)


------
by neigal 28.01.22

metadata.name: DIGITAL DISOBEDIENCE #1
metadata.description:
As artists, we believe it is our duty to use our skills to comment on the state of the world and the pressing issues facing humanity. Through our art, we aim to pre-empt the future and explore the potential consequences of our current actions. We use symmetry as a visual metaphor for the balance we must strive for in society, particularly in regards to human rights and the treatment of marginalized groups. In the age of technology and AI advancements, it is more important than ever to consider the impact these developments may have on our world and the diverse individuals and communities that inhabit it. Our work serves as a reminder that we must take responsibility for our actions and work towards creating a more just and equitable future for all.

This token is part of the Floor Exhibit co-curated by the NFT Museum of Newberry, SC and Fort Gallery NFT.

metadata.name: Inefficient Ways of Independence #42
metadata.description:
"Inefficient Ways of Independence" is a thought - provoking artwork that explores the relationship between technology and the human experience.

The piece features a collection of iconic symbols of old technology, such as closed - circuit TV cameras, floppy disks, and vintage Mac computers, coupled together by a flow of particles.

The use of human body parts or heads adds a personal touch to the work, highlighting the intimate connection between the individual and technology.

The title "Inefficient Ways of Independence" serves as a commentary on our dependence on technology and the way that it has changed over time.

It also raises questions about our relationship with technology and the limitations that it can impose.

The piece invites the viewer to consider how technology has shaped our lives and to reflect on the consequences of our reliance on it.

This token is part of the Floor Exhibit co-curated by the NFT Museum of Newberry, SC and Fort Gallery NFT

metadata.name: Cosmic Overlay #61
metadata.description:
This is the second part of the overlay collection.
Inspired by its predecessor, this collection creates different mountain landscapes, in different atmosphere.
